title: WCAS ASIAN_LC 390-0-22 Advanced Topics in Asian Languages and Cultures

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Mughal Empire (1526-1857) is widely remembered as one of the most powerful, opulent empires of the early modern world, renowned both for the atmosphere of cultural pluralism that it promoted as well as the magnificient monuments (such as the famed Taj Mahal) that it produced. Less well known, however, are the remarkably rich - and remarkably diverse - literary cultures that the Mughal court promoted, and which saturated the cultural, political, and religious life of early modern India more generally. This course will introduce students to some of the basic features of these intersecting Indo-Persian, Sanskrit, and Hindi-Urdu literary worlds (in translation, of course), as well as to their lasting - and sometimes controversial - legacies in modern South Asian culture and politics, from British India to Bollywood.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None - but "History of Early Modern India" (HIS 385-1) and/or "History of Modern South Asia" (HIS 385-2) are recommended.
